```{r}
#
# Convert time stamps to survey names
#

# Strip off the clock time and leave just the date
dat$Surveyed <-gsub(" .*","",dat$Surveyed)

# Set survey groupings
for(i in 1:length(dat$Surveyed)) {
  if(str_detect(dat$Surveyed[i], "2019")) {
    dat$Surveyed[i] <- "1F19"
  }
  if(dat$Surveyed[i] != "1F19" & dat$Surveyed[i] > "1/1/2020" & dat$Surveyed[i] < "4/1/2020") {
    dat$Surveyed[i] <- "2W20"
  }
  if(dat$Surveyed[i] != "1F19" & dat$Surveyed[i] > "4/1/2020" & dat$Surveyed[i] < "6/30/2020") {
    dat$Surveyed[i] <- "3S20"
  }
  if(dat$Surveyed[i] != "1F19" & dat$Surveyed[i] > "7/1/2020" & dat$Surveyed[i] < "9/30/2020") {
    dat$Surveyed[i] <- "4S20"
  }
}

# Remove rows below the actual data / Remove Comments
dat <- subset(dat, dat[ , 1] != "") 

# Convert text to numbers
dat[dat == "1 - Strongly Disagree"]  <- 1
dat[dat == "4 - Disagree"]           <- 4
dat[dat == "7 - Agree"]              <- 7
dat[dat == "10 - Strongly Agree"]    <- 10
dat[dat == "NA or Do Not Use"]       <- 0
dat[is.na(dat)]                      <- 0
dat[dat == "0"]                      <- 0
dat[dat == ""]                       <- 0

```

**Department Participant Comparison by Quarter**

Participants were selected by random from the total population of active church employees as they were in the previous two surveys. A program was used to select a random sample that would result in the fewest number of overlaps relative to those already surveyed during the fall and winter. This reduced the number of repeat responders to 8. 

The profile of those surveyed generally shows a departmental distribution similar to those in the past. The survey does not collect email addresses, and so we do not know the distribution of *responses* by department. Some highlights:

* The CSM was relatively more represented as it has been in the past
* We had 52 responses, which is noticeably more than we have received in the past (average of 41)
* The 52 responses represent a 41% response rate, which is very good

The survey distribution by quarter and department is shown below.

```{r Main Report Code, echo=FALSE}
################################################################################
#
# Create dataframes for reporting
#
################################################################################

# Create the dataframes to hold all the results
res_df     <- data.frame(Quarter = 1:6,   Grp = 1:6,   Question = 1:6,   Avg = 1:6)

res_df_am  <- data.frame(Quarter = 1:6,   Grp = 1:6,   Question = 1:6,   Avg = 1:6)
res_df_ba  <- data.frame(Quarter = 1:6,   Grp = 1:6,   Question = 1:6,   Avg = 1:6)
res_df_bm  <- data.frame(Quarter = 1:6,   Grp = 1:6,   Question = 1:6,   Avg = 1:6)
res_df_ps  <- data.frame(Quarter = 1:6,   Grp = 1:6,   Question = 1:6,   Avg = 1:6)
res_df_sd  <- data.frame(Quarter = 1:6,   Grp = 1:6,   Question = 1:6,   Avg = 1:6)
res_df_vm  <- data.frame(Quarter = 1:6,   Grp = 1:6,   Question = 1:6,   Avg = 1:6)

grp_x_qtr  <- list(res_df_am, res_df_ba, res_df_bm, res_df_ps, res_df_sd, res_df_vm)
full_year  <- list(Q1 = grp_x_qtr, Q2 = grp_x_qtr, Q3 = grp_x_qtr, Q4 = grp_x_qtr)
groups <- c("AM", "BA", "BMPS", "PS", "SD", "VM")
questions <- c("1A", "1B", "1C", "2A", "2B", "3x")

#-------------------------------------------------------------------------------
#
# Work through each breakdown - by quarter, then group, then question
#
#-------------------------------------------------------------------------------

# Build out groupings by OCIO department
am_results  <- transform(dat[c(1, 2, 8,14,20,26,32)])
ba_results  <- transform(dat[c(1, 3, 9,15,21,27,33)])
bm_results  <- transform(dat[c(1, 4,10,16,22,28,34)])
ps_results  <- transform(dat[c(1, 5,11,17,23,29,35)])
sd_results  <- transform(dat[c(1, 6,12,18,24,30,36)])
vm_results  <- transform(dat[c(1, 7,13,19,25,31,37)])

results_list <- list(am_results, ba_results, bm_results, ps_results, sd_results, vm_results)

#
# Process each group, quarter by quarter
#

# Establish the quarter
for(a in 1:length(unique(dat$Surveyed))) {
  quarter <- unique(dat$Surveyed)[a]
  
  # Outer loop to establish the group and data
  for(i in 1:length(groups)) {
    group <- groups[i]
    group_data <- as.data.frame(results_list[i])
    group_data <- group_data %>% filter(Surveyed == quarter)
    group_data <- group_data %>% select(-Surveyed)
  
   # Establish the number of responses in this group
    x <- nrow(group_data)
    
    # Create a dataframe to hold the six answers as numberics
    new_df <- data.frame(Q1A = 1:x, Q1B = 1:x, Q1C = 1:x, Q2A = 1:x, Q2B = 1:x, Q3x = 1:x)
    
    # Next loop to write the numeric values to the new dataframe
    for(j in 1:x) {
      for(k in 1:6) {
        if(group_data[j,k] == "0") {
          new_df[j,k] = 0
          }
        if(group_data[j,k] == "1") {
          new_df[j,k] = 1
        }
        if(group_data[j,k] == "2") {
          new_df[j,k] = 2
        }
        if(group_data[j,k] == "3") {
          new_df[j,k] = 3
        }
        if(group_data[j,k] == "4") {
          new_df[j,k] = 4
        }
        if(group_data[j,k] == "5") {
          new_df[j,k] = 5
        }
        if(group_data[j,k] == "6") {
          new_df[j,k] = 6
        }
        if(group_data[j,k] == "7") {
          new_df[j,k] = 7
        }
        if(group_data[j,k] == "8") {
          new_df[j,k] = 8
        }
        if(group_data[j,k] == "9") {
          new_df[j,k] = 9
        }
        if(group_data[j,k] == "10") {
          new_df[j,k] = 10
        }
      }
    }
    for(m in 1:6) {
      
      # Clear out the NR and DNUs
      y <- new_df[m] == 0
      z <- length(y[y == TRUE])
      
      # Calculate the mean
      mean_new_df <- round(sum(new_df[m]) / (x - z), digits = 1)
      
      # write the results to the dataframe
      res_df[m,1]  <- quarter
      res_df[m,2]  <- group
      res_df[m,3]  <- questions[m]
      res_df[m,4]  <- mean_new_df
    }
    # Now we have the entire quarter for each group
    grp_x_qtr[[i]] <- res_df
  }
  # Until I can figure out how to access parts of a list by indexing alone, we 
  # loop through to make sure the results for the quarter to the right place
  if(a == 1) {
    full_year$Q1 <- grp_x_qtr
  }
  if(a == 2) {
    full_year$Q2 <- grp_x_qtr
  }
  if(a == 3) {
    full_year$Q3 <- grp_x_qtr
  }
  if(a == 4) {
    full_year$Q4 <- grp_x_qtr
  }
}
```

`r pagebreak()`
**Recap of Survey Questions**

* 1A. TSG representatives are always able to understand my problems / needs  
* 1B. TSG representatives ask the right questions and listen to my input  
* 1C. TSG representatives stay in touch until my problems are resolved or my needs are met  
* 2A. TSG representatives always have the knowledge to address my needs  
* 2B. TSG representatives address my needs completely and professionally  
* 3X. TSG representatives always resolve my needs or problems within my required time-frames  

**Summary of Results (Fall 2019, Winter 2020, and Spring 2020)**

Some observations relative to group performance:

* Account Managers: showed a slight decline (0.2 points) from Winter 2020
* Business Analysts: improved noticeably (0.7) from the Winter
* B&MPS and Service Desk, generally the strongest performers, were unchanged
* Project Support improved the most, going up on average 1.35 points per question
* Vendor Managers were up slightly (0.3) and returned to Fall 2019 levels

Some observations relative to performance by question. The headline here is that **all** questions improved their results since the last survey:

* 1A. understand my problems / needs **(+0.4)**
* 1B. ask the right questions and listen to my input **(+0.2)**
* 1C. stay in touch until my problems are resolved **(+0.4)**  
* 2A. have the knowledge to address my needs **(+0.2)**
* 2B. address my needs completely and professionally  **(+0.5)**
* 3X. resolve my needs or problems within my required time-frames **(+0.6)**

As shown, the biggest gains were made in what have been weaker areas in past surveys: on-time performance and speed of resolution.

Where gains were made, they were fueled primarily by the *Business Analysis*, *Project Support*, and *Vendor Managers* groups. This is particularly good to see, as these groups appeared to be where improvement was most needed.

```{r Graphics - Summaries, echo=FALSE}
x = 0

  # Data is all Q1 - so column 1 is always Q1-F19
  qbq_q1_df[i,1] <- "Q1F19"
  
  # Take each of the 6 questions in order
  qbq_q1_df[i,2] <- questions[i]
  for(j in 1:6) {
    
    # For each group, compute the totals for each question
    x <- x + full_year$Q1[[j]]$Avg[i]
  }
  
  # Compute the average of scores and assign to the data frame 
  x <- x / 6
  qbq_q1_df[i,3] <- round(x, digits = 1)
  
  # Reset x so that we can compute the next total and average
  x = 0
}
```
